com.diffplug.common.swt

Class ControlWrapper<T extends org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Control>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.diffplug.common.swt.ControlWrapper<T>

  • public class ControlWrapper<T extends org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Control>
extends java.lang.Object
    Wraps an SWT Control to hide its API. The traditional way to make a custom class is this: `class CustomControl extends Composite` This has three main problems: - Users can add random widgets to your "Control" because it exposes the Composite interface. - Users can set the layout oo your "Control" because it exposes the Composite interface. - Users can add random listeners to your "Control", and overridding "addListener" to intercept them is a VERY DANGEROUS PLAN. ControlWrapper fixes this by providing an extremely low-overhead skeleton which encapsulates the SWT Control that you're using as the base of your custom control, which allows you to only expose the APIs that are appropriate.

      • asControl

        public org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Control asControl()
        Returns the wrapped widget as a raw Control. Useful for writing SWT code that needs the Control instance such as DND code. The returned Control is not exposed as T on purpose.
